CatDescriptText: Gerald William Jackson, porter, Homewood and Cedric Williams, postal clerk, Hill District, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, May 19, 1962, pg. 9 with question: "Do you think that, eventually, the City of Pittsburgh will come to include the outlying suburbs under a metropolitan plan of government?"  Mr. Jackson's answer reads: "Eventually, all these towns will get together.  It would be better if there was one system of streets, water, government.  We would get better service."  Mr. Williams' answer reads: "Yes.  I think Los Angeles has this sort of plan, as do many other cities.  Eventually all the large cities will adopt it.  Pittsburgh, the same.  At least it would ease the burden on the transportation system."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Gerald William Jackson wearing fedora and cardigan with light colored buttons, standing in front of store window with signs that read "Rain Jacket 1.87" and "Casting Reel 3.99"; Portrait of Cedric Williams wearing moustache and polka dot short sleeve shirt, standing in front of store window with sign that reads "Golf Balls 5.44"
